item.title: Comment on Monday assorted links by mkt42
item.description:
"6. Eel vs. octopus (NYT)."

"A 2022 observation recorded in Las Minas Islet, Cantabrian Sea off northwestern Spain, in which the eel lost an eyeball in the battle"

Spain is also where those orcas are attacking sailboats. Imagine if octopus decided to start attacking human swimmers and divers, choking them and removing their eyeballs.

Come to think of it, how do fishermen catch octopus? According to articles on the web, one common technique is similar to catching lobster or crab: a trap with bait inside, that the octopus enters but can't get out. Or won't get out, surely an octopus could exit if it wanted to, given their ability to squeeze through tiny cracks.

And in the 1990s Japanese fishermen invented a new type of lure and technique called egi, basically a lure made to look and move like a small fish, inducing the octopus (or squid) to strike and I guess get impaled on the hook.
https://www.thefisherman.com/article/plugging-for-squid-the-art-of-eging/

item.title: Comment on Innovation Matters by notkevinnealon
item.description:
“But if you focus on innovation you can get high growth and then people are much less concerned with redistribution.“
This thought seems rational but is 100% wrong. Citizens *should* be thrilled with absolute growth that improves everyone’s standard of living and yet the irrational monkey parts of our brain are so focussed on fairness that being richer in absolute terms but poorer in relative terms makes one feel anger that they have been ripped off. Internet influencers and billionaires as celebrities are a heavy grit sandpaper that chafes even worse. As a child, my father crapped in an outhouse in the bitter cold of winter and never felt poor because he saw his friends doing the same. Then came Robin Leach and Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous.

item.title: Comment on Innovation Matters by Neurotic
item.description:
Reply to Bob:

More like 'stop incentivizing people to study things that don't help much at all, in schools where students have poor outcomes' There is a huge variance in degree utility, yet we spend large amounts of money pretending that there isn't, which makes more people end up with low quality degrees that cost them, and us, far more than they help. It's like having the labor theory of value, but in education.

BAs with no/low marketable value = elephant whistles. Note that elephant whistles don't do nothing: they can create & reinforce confidence.
